Om Birla.description: NEW DELHI: The new Lok Sabha Speaker, Om Birla, a two-time BJP MP from Rajasthan, is a relative newcomer for the post traditionally held by seniors.   A surprise pick by the ruling BJP-led NDA   , Birla's name was proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi himself for the post, sources said. The 56-year-old leader is considered to be close to both Modi and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) president Amit Shah. Birla's nomination for the Lok Sabha Speaker's post also has the   backing of non-NDA parties   such as the YSR Congress Party (YSRCP) and the Biju Janata Dal (BJD). Starting his political journey as a student leader, Birla was also elected to the Rajasthan Assembly for three consecutive terms in 2003, 2008 and 2013. He won his first Lok Sabha election in 2014 and was again elected this year from Rajasthan's Kota-Bundi seat. Birla defeated Congress's Ramnarayan Meena with a margin of over 2.5 lakh votes in the recently-concluded general election. A conscientious parliamentarian, Birla has registered an 86-per cent average attendance in the House, asked 671 questions, participated in 163 debates and introduced six private members' bills in the 16th Lok Sabha. From 1991 to 2003, he was a key leader in the Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha (BJYM) as a state-level president first and then, as a vice-president at the national level. Birla, who holds a Masters degree in commerce, is a member of the Standing Committee on Energy in Parliament, the Committee on Petitions and the Consultative Committee for the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment. He succeeds eight-time MP Sumitra Mahajan as the Lok Sabha Speaker, a post traditionally held by senior MPs. However, this is not the first time that a relative newcomer has occupied the position. In 1996, Telugu Desam Party (TDP) leader G M C Balayogi, also a two-time MP then, was elected as the Speaker in the Lower House of Parliament. After his death in a helicopter crash in 2002, Shiv Sena leader and first-time MP Manohar Joshi was appointed to the position. Heatwave kills 90 people in last 72 hour.description: PATNA: Severe heatwave killed 12 more people in Bihar in the past 24 hours, taking the death toll over the past three days to 90, official said on Tuesday. However unofficially, the heatwave has claimed more than 250 lives in three days across a dozen districts. Deaths were reported from Aurangabad, Gaya, Nawada and Jamui districts, where temperatures hovered around 45.8 to 42 degrees Celsius on June 15, 16 and 17. According to the state disaster management department website, some 90 deaths had been recorded till Tuesday. Of these, Aurangabad recorded 41 deaths, Gaya 35 and Nawada 14. In a first, prohibitory orders have been imposed in the wake of extreme weather conditions under Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in Gaya, Begusarai, Darbhanga, Gopalganj, Madhubani and Sitamarhi districts Bihar chief secretary Deepak Kumar told the media here that the government will conduct an inquiry into how intense the heatwave was between 3-5 p.m. on June 15 that it resulted in the highest number of deaths in a day due to heatstroke. Kumar said the chief minister had also ordered an environment survey of the state over the next four days. Chief minister Nitish Kumar has already announced a compensation of Rs 4 lakh to the kin of the victims. The government has also issued a heat alert and advised people to avoid going out during the day time. Additional health director of Magadh range Dr Vijay Kumar said that nearly 100 people had been admitted in government-run hospitals in Gaya, Aurangabad and Nawada, while dozens were being treated at primary health centres in the three districts. Encephalitis deaths: Ayushman Bharat, CM.description: MUZAFFARPUR/PATNA: The ambitious Ayushman Bharat scheme of the Narendra Modi government as well as several Bihar government initiatives failed the over 100 kids who died of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) at the two Muzaffarpur hospitals. Health officials conceded that none of the kids, who have survived the deadly ‘chamki bukhar’ or are undergoing treatment, has been provided assistance under Ayushman Bharat — a flagship scheme under the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY). A senior official in the state health department confirmed that treatment of AES can be covered under the scheme. PMJAY, launched during the first term of the Modi government, provides an annual health cover of Rs 5 lakh per family to nearly 50 crore people from 10.74 crore ‘deprived’ families selected on the basis of socio-economic and caste census data. Bihar government’s Mukhya Mantri Chikitsa Sahayta Kosh Yojna is also aimed at providing monetary assistance to the poor for medical treatment of the disease. However, both these initiatives failed to come to the rescue. Muzaffarpur civil surgeon Shailesh Prasad Singh told TOI on Wednesday that no applications of AES patients were received either at the state government- run Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) or the trust-run Krishnadevi Deviprasad Kejriwal Maternity Hospital. G S Sahni, head of pediatrics department at SKMCH, said treatment of AES cases is covered under both the central and the state schemes.  “SKMCH as well as KDKMH are listed under Ayushman Bharat scheme along with all 16 primary health centres (PHCs) two additional PHCs, two referral hospitals in the district are listed Ayushman Bharat scheme,” he said, adding that 10 private hospitals in the district are also enlisted listed for treating people under the central scheme. Incidentally, none of the private hospitals listed under Ayushman Bharat scheme have pediatric intensive care units and only two of them have general ICUs. Relatives of a number of children admitted at SKMCH and KDKMH claimed that they have not even been issued the health cards under Ayushman Bharat scheme. “We have not been issued health card for getting treated under Ayushman Bharat scheme. Hence, we have not applied for it,” said Poona Devi, whose son Raushan Raj (5) succumbed to the deadly disease on June 14. Devi is a resident of Dariapur Kafen village under Kanti block of the district. On being asked about getting the ailing children treated at the ICUs of private hospitals, Muzaffarpur DM Alok Ranjan Ghosh said it cannot be done due to technical and administrative issues. “We cannot shift the children from PICUs of SKMCH to any private hospital because it will create chaos at management level. If any death occurs at those hospitals, we cannot fix the responsibility on anyone. Even having an eye of treatment procedure at those private hospitals would be a hectic and lengthy task. So, we are not preferring to shift the children to a private nursing home,” Ghosh said. The DM added that it has also been observed that the Matrisadan hospital has been referring the cases to SKMCH in the eleventh hour. “It becomes very difficult to save the life of the kid, when they are referred to SKMCH in critical condition,” Ghosh said. Health experts also claimed that the outbreak of the disease also showed failure of the state and central government to spread awareness about its prevention. “AES has been occurring from over past two decades and few common causes have been identified as low glucose level and malnutrition and its occurrence in peak summer season. But the disease still claimed lives of over 100 children, this year. This shows that the authorities utterly failed to create even awareness about the disease,” said Sanjay Kumar, secretary of Patna chapter of IMA. Purnea University: Online admission proc.description: PATNA: Purnea University began the online process for admission to different postgraduate (PG) courses from Tuesday. The last date for submitting applications for the 2019-20 academic session is June 30. “The registration fee for general category candidates is Rs 1,000 each and that for SC/ST and OBC candidates is Rs 700 each. We will inform the shortlisted candidates after going through their applications in the first week of July,” Purnea University vice-chancellor (VC) Rajesh Singh told this newspaper. The university has invited online applications for admission to PG courses like physics, chemistry, mathematics, botany, zoology, Maithili, Hindi, English, Sanskrit, Urdu, Bangla, philosophy, psychology, economics, sociology, geography, home science, history, political science, music, Persian and commerce. Applications have also been invited for PG courses being taught at Purnea Mahila College and D S College-Katihar. “Students can apply online for admission to 12 self-financing courses as well. They include master of physical education, MSc in food science and technology, MSc in molecular breeding, PG diploma in green house technology, MSc in fisheries science, MSc in bioinformatics, MSc in geographic information system and remote sensing, MSc in horticulture and landscape, PG diploma in astrology and palmistry, Masters in company secretaryship, MBA and Master of Laws,” the VC said, adding the registration fee for general category students was Rs 1,000 each and that for others was Rs 800 each. According to the VC, the self-financing courses at the PG level are career-oriented. He said, “On successful completion of these courses, a student can work with reputed multinational companies as well as governmental organizations.” Purnea University has signed memoranda of understanding with several foreign universities to run its self-financing courses smoothly. Their faculty members have also agreed to teach students here. Entrance test: Purnea University is busy preparing for its maiden combined entrance test to be conducted for admission to different three-year undergraduate (UG) courses in arts, science and commerce streams on June 30. More than 80,000 students have applied for admissions. “They will be shortlisted for admission in different constituent and affiliated colleges of the university on the basis of their performance in the written test,” the VC said. Students from foreign countries like Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh and neighbouring states of Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam are also seeking admission to various courses of the university this year. Tejasvi Surya.description: BENGALURU: From a boy who was groomed by late Union minister H N Ananth Kumar and Tejaswini Ananth Kumar to becoming the challenge to the family’s control over Bengaluru South segment, Tejasvi Surya has come a long way.While expressing his gratitude to Kumar and his family, Surya says he is a stark example of the BJP’s intent to infuse young and new blood. You were a surprise choice for Bengaluru South. Did you expect this development?While I had feelers that there was something like this going around, I was quite happily savouring pani puri with my friends. To be honest I was overwhelmed and started tweeting about this. I only feel gratitude towards the party, which is facing a crucial election and has decided to take risk by fielding a youngster in such a prestigious seat. At 28, will you be able to fill the shoes of Kumar?Filling the shoes of Ananth Kumar is a far fetched thing for he was so gigantic. I only pray to God to give me strength, sincerity and earnestness to honestly work for the people of this constituency so that one day in the eyes of the people I can match up to Kumar’s contribution to the constituency. On lack of political experience, I have a well oiled party organisational machinery to support me with senior leaders there to hand hold me. So what is this election going to be for you?Primarily it is an election for PM Narendra Modi’s aspirational India. It is about the promise of a new and young India and I am just an ambassador of the message of this new India. It is a reflection of party and Modi’s inclination of bringing in young blood. Tejaswini not getting the ticket is quite sensitive...Yes it is sensitive but even during her talk with the Karyakartas she told them that the it was time to show maturity. She has given her full support to me. But what is your personal opinion about Tejaswini missing the ticket?When her name was first finalised by the state leadership, it must be March 11, I was the first to extend my support to her and remember posting on social media that she was the most deserving candidate and a good choice from the constituency. But the party decided to field an ordinary karyakarta like me. It is a decision taken by big people and I am just a foot soldier obeying their diktat. I have always supported Tejaswini ma’am and was literally groomed by that family. I have no reason for acrimony. Statements by Karti Chidamabaram suggest that you are the Schutzstaffel of BJP, or the infamous SS of the Nazi Germany... Your tweets also suggest that your idealogical beliefs are in conflict with the “Sab Ka Saath Sab Ka Vikas” For Karti Chidambaram and others I will reply back to them in their own coin. The idealogical inclinations are not an issue for this election. The issue for the election today, is PM Modi’s promise of a new and superpower India. My only concern as on today is to ensure that Bangalore South elects the BJP with a massive margin so that we will strengthen Modi hands. Rest is immaterial. Is age an advantage or do you require time to project yourself as a leader?That the party leadership has reposed faith in me speaks for itself and the least minimum I can do is to live up to it and say I am capable enough as on today to take on these challenges. You must rise to the occasion and I will rise to it. On dynasty politics, considering you are a nephew of a sitting BJP MLA and PM Modi has gone on the offensive against the Congress on the issue of “Naamdar”...My candidature and my role and activity in politics has no connection to my uncle’s political life. I have an identity of my own and have worked very hard over years. My aspirations precedes his elections. If the party leadership thought I was a rise to another dynast, they would not have considered me at all. Woman gangraped in Patna, two arrested.description: PATNA: A 19-year-old married woman was allegedly gangraped by two persons at a secluded place below Rajendra Nagar overbridge near Dinkar roundabout here on Tuesday at around 2am. Police has arrested two persons in connection with the incident. The arrested persons had been identified as Ranjeet Kumar (30), a painter by profession while another arrested person was identified as Chotu Kumar (28), an e-rickshaw driver. Their associate Deepak Kumar (25), who is also an e-rickshaw driver, had been kept in police custody to ascertain if he had any role in the incident or not. All three are residents of Lohanipur locality under Kadamkuan police station area. The panchayat held a meeting on Monday on the request of the girl’s father in-law, a resident of Bagaha subdivision in West Champaran district. The panchayat had summoned both Ranju (name changed) and her paramour, a resident of Naurangia village, to settle the issue as her husband wanted to part ways with her after the Sunday incident. Police said on Tuesday Ranju was married about two months ago when her father came to know about her intimate relationship with a boy. Though Ranju did not protest the marriage under family pressure, she remained in touch with her paramour. They used to meet frequently when her husband went to Gujarat for earning livelihood. On Sunday night, Ranju and her paramour were thrashed. When the father revealed the matter to her husband, the latter refused to stay with his wife. Subsequently, the matter was taken up by the panchayat, which ordered the girl’s relatives to tie their hands and thrash them in full public. “The girl’s father was not in favour of his daughter’s marriage with her paramour as they belonged to two different castes,” a police officer posted at Valmikinagar police station said. The police, later, rescued Ranju and her paramour and brought them to the police station. Bagaha SP Rajiv Ranjan said it was being ascertained whether both they were adults or not. “The police will initiate action against the members of the panchayat on the basis of evidence,” he said. Both Ranju and the boy told the police that they wanted to marry. “My father married me against my wishes. Now I want to stay with my boyfriend, who will take care of me,” she reportedly told the interrogators. They were at the police station till late Tuesday evening. Muzzafarpur Encephalitis deaths: Nitish.description: MUZAFFARPUR: RJD leader Raghuvansh Prasad Singh on Wednesday said that Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar should resign from his post on moral grounds over the death of over 100 children Muzaffarpur due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES). "The one who has the steering in his hands, shouldn't he run the vehicle properly? The steering is in chief minister's hands. Then who else will be held responsible for this. He (Nitish Kumar) should himself resign on the basis of morality. Since many years, they couldn't find a cure to this disease and maintain the hospitals. Also, they didn't fulfill whatever they promised," Singh told ANI here. "The state government is responsible for this. Since last 15-20 years, children have been dying because of this. But who takes note of the deaths in rural areas? Around 300-400 children have died there. Secondly, every year specialists come here but it has not been found yet why this disease is breaking out. Somebody said it is because of litchi fruit, while the other said it is because of heat wave," he added. Singh criticised the facilities provided at SKMCH for patients and said, "There are no basic facilities provided in hospital... SKMCH is hell. People can't walk in the hospital without covering nose. Railways completes RRI work at Danapur s.description: PATNA: Work on the route relay interlocking (RRI) system, which began at Danapur station under the East Central Railway (ECR) on June 8, was completed on Monday. According to Danapur divisional railway manager (DRM) Ranjan Prakash Thakur, as many as 1,000 railway staff from signalling, traffic and engineering departments worked round the clock to complete the work in record time. “The Danapur yard, which had been functioning through a manual system for almost 60 years, has now been modernized. The new RRI system will be tested till June 19 to ensure that it is snag-free. However, normal traffic movement on the Patna-Danapur-Buxar-Pt Deendayal Upadhyay Junction route will be restored from June 20,” Thakur said. Danapur is the third station, after Jhajha and Patna Junction in the Danapur division, which is equipped with RRI system. Thakur told this newspaper, “The railways completed this project at a cost of Rs 50 crore. The biggest advantage of the RRI system is that it will ensure foolproof safety on the tracks and avert head-on collisions of trains. Besides, there will not be chances of signal failure and detention of trains at outer signals. This will improve the punctuality of passenger trains.” The railways has also built a separate RRI cabin at the Danapur station from where movement of passenger and goods trains can be controlled safely. Experts visit Muzaffarpur hospital to fi.description: PATNA/MUZAFFARPUR: Health agencies and experts from across the country have started visiting Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur again to find the cause of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), which has claimed at least 107 lives this season and more than 1000 over the last one decade. Dr Gopal Shankar Sahni, head of paediatrics department at SKMCH, said several teams of experts and doctors from National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), Delhi, National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, and All India Institutes of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Delhi and Patna have come to Muzaffarpur to study the cases and find the cause of AES, which has been occurring during peak summer and pre-monsoon season in the north Bihar district since 1994-95. Incidentally, most of these agencies and organizations had conducted studies on the disease in the past as well. “They are taking blood, urine and throat sob samples of the affected children. Besides, they will be studying the profile of the victims and their food habits, common places of occurrence of the disease, among others,” Dr Sahni told TOI on Tuesday. He said researchers have so far failed to reach any conclusion. He attributed the disease to extreme heat and humidity. “The AES outbreak mostly happened when the maximum temperature remained above 38 degrees C and humidity was in the range of 60-70% and above,” he said. Patna-based Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) doctor has suggested brain biopsy and tissue culture of the victims to know the cause of AES deaths. “Following the inspection of SKMCH by Union health minister recently, the state government had asked IGIMS to suggest steps for finding the cause of the disease. Based on a detailed study and deliberations on researches done by agencies across the globe on the disease in Muzaffarpur, we have recommended brain biopsy in death cases and brain tissue biopsy in case of fever,” IGIMS medical superintendent Dr Manish Mandal told TOI. He said majority of the researches have been based on blood samples only. Doctors at SKMCH, however, claimed the studies conducted in the past were not based on blood samples only. “The researches conducted by the NIV-Pune, NCDC and CDC-Atlanta between 2011 and 2013 were based on a number of samples, including blood, urine, cerebrospinal sasal fluid, rectal sob, nasal sob and throat secretin. NIV, in fact, had conducted even brain biopsy in one case. However, no virus was found to be the cause of the disease in any of the studies and viral encephalitis was ruled out. The studies put the disease in the category of non-inflammatory encephalopathy,” Dr Sahni said. On being asked why brain biopsy was not done in suspected AES cases, Dr Sahni said: “Biopsy and other forms of autopsies are done only in the case of unnatural deaths. However, the AES deaths are natural due to some disease,” he said. The other researches on the AES, locally known as ‘Chamki Bukhar (high fever with seizure)’, include those published in journals of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta and The Lancet Global Health medical journal in 2017. Different studies and researches have blamed different causes of the disease, including malnourishment, binge-eating litchi on empty stomach and even heatstroke. Muzaffarpur-based Dr Arun Shah, who is a member of national executive committee of the Indian Paediatrics Association, said the CDC study had attributed the disease to acute hypoglycaemic encephalopathy, which is caused due to extreme low level of blood glucose in the body. “Under-nutrition is a common trend observed in most of the children suffering from the AES as they belong to poor families. The CDC, in its recommendations, had advised parents of the area not to allow their children to venture out in the orchards and feed them properly before going to sleep,” said Dr Shah. Parents of several victims also accepted under-nutrition. Nunu Mahto, who lost his 4-year-old son Prince on June 10 due to AES, said his son had consumed nothing on June 7 night. He was convulsing next morning. “We tried to admit him to Kanti primary health centre, but they did not respond. Finally, we took him to SKMCH where he died,” Nunu said. Patna: Hospitals take measures to handle.description: PATNA: The government hospitals in city have initiated several measures to deal with heatstroke cases following an advisory issued by Bihar State Health Society (SHS), a wing of health department. The government hospitals have earmarked separate beds in ICU and general wards for heatstroke patients. Doctors and nurses of general wards have been asked to give priority to patients suffering from heat-related ailments like fever, nausea, dehydration and cramps. Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) medical superintendent Dr Manish Mandal told this newspaper that five beds each in ICU and general ward have been earmarked for heatstroke patients. “The hospital is equipped to tackle such routine cases. However, no heatstroke case has been reported at IGIMS so far,” he said. Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) has a separate ward with five beds for heatstroke patients. No control room has been set up at the hospital as the number of cases is not alarming, said PMCH superintendent Dr Rajiv Ranjan Prasad. Dr Rajiv said two or three patients are admitted and get discharged after treatment per day. “The airconditioned ward for heatstroke patients is equipped with ventilator, oxygen mask and cylinder besides required drugs and fluids,” he said. At AIIMS-Patna, the internal medicine department has instructed the doctors to treat heatstroke patients on priority basis. Head of internal medicine department, Dr Ravi Kirti, said the hospital is well-equipped with required drugs and electrolyte, ORS and fluids. “We are prepared to handle patients of heatstroke and don’t require any special arrangements for that,” he told this newspaper. Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH) medical superintendent Dr Chandra Shekhar said the hospital meets all the requirements mentioned in the advisory issued by the health department. “We have ample ORS, electrolyte and paracetamol to treat heatstroke patients,” he added. Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Muzaffarpur's SKMCH to be upgraded into.description: PATNA: The Muzaffarpur-based state-run Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH), which is in the news these days because of the deaths of several children due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES), will be upgraded into a 2,500-bed hospital in next two years. The hospital currently has 610 beds. Bihar CM Nitish Kumar on Tuesday asked the state’s principal secretary (health) Sanjay Kumar to make arrangements of at least 1,500 beds in the hospital a year as part of the first phase of upgradation. CM gave this direction to health department officials after visiting the SKMCH where he talked to the parents and attendants of affected children, doctors and the college principal and tried to know about the reasons behind the occurrence of the AES almost every year in certain parts of north Bihar, especially three to four blocks of Muzaffarpur district. Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, chief secretary Deepak Kumar and principal secretary (health) Sanjay Kumar accompanied the CM during his visit to the SKMCH. “CM also asked the health officials to establish a 100-bed special paediatric intensive care unit (ICU) at the SKMCH in next one year to deal with the children-related diseases,” chief secretary Deepak Kumar told media persons in Patna while briefing about the CM’s visit to the SKMCH. He said, the SKMCH currently has a 50-bed paediatric ICU, it would now be upgraded into a 100-bed ICU as per the CM’s instruction. Chief secretary further said, the CM also instructed for building a big dharamshala (rest house) near the SKMCH so that the poor parents and attendants visiting the hospital do no face problem of accommodation. Accompanied by the principal secretary (health), chief secretary said all the instructions given by the CM would be completed within the stipulated period. “CM also instructed for deputing more paediatric doctors at the SKMCH to assist the existing doctors,” the chief secretary said, adding as per the instructions more doctors from the Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) and the Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital (DMCH) were being rushed to the SKMCH. Sanjay said, at present altogether 31 paediatricians are working at the the SKMCH. Eight more paediatricians from other hospitals would be reporting the SKMCH by Tuesday night. Chief secretary also claimed that the CM and the deputy CM visited almost all beds where AES-affected children are getting treatment. They talked to the parents and attendants of almost all AES-affected children, but not a single parent complaint about any sort of mismanagement or negligence on the part of the doctors at the SKMCH. All parents expressed their satisfaction on the arrangements at the SKMCH. Chief secretary also said the free ambulance service was being provided to the AES-affected children. “If any parent of AES-affected child reaches the hospital by hiring vehicle by own, the state government has decided to reimburse Rs 400 per patient at a flat rate in the name of hiring ambulance or vehicle,” he said. Heatstroke claims five more lives in Bih.description: PATNA: With the death of five more people in the last 24 hours, heatwave toll in four districts of Bihar – Gaya, Aurangabad, Nawada and Jamui – went up to 83 on Tuesday. According to figures available on the official website of state disaster management department, 35 people have so far died in Gaya, 34 in Aurangabad, 12 in Nawada and two in Jamui due to heatstroke. Majority of the deceased were above the age of 60 years. Over 150 persons are still undergoing treatment at different government hospitals in the four districts. Though several places in the state witnessed thundershower and rain late on Monday night, there was no let-up in high temperature and humidity. Section 144 of CrPC (illegal assembly) has already been imposed in the three worst-affected districts of Gaya, Aurangabad and Nawada, banning all construction activities and assembly of people in the open between 11am and 4pm. This is perhaps the first time that Section 144 has been imposed in the state due to extreme weather condition. The law, which is usually invoked to control law and order, has been used so that the people avoid going outside their homes in the blistering heat. All government and private schools as well as coaching institutes have been asked to keep their institutions shut till June 22. Gaya additional district magistrate (incharge) Mohammad Blaghuddin said cheques for Rs 4 lakh each were handed over to the next of kin of the 12 deceased in the district. “Seven of the victims were from other districts. Their names and addresses are being verified. Once the process is complete, the cheques will be handed over to the respective family members,” Blaghuddin told this newspaper over the phone. A senior official of the Aurangabad district administration said cheques for Rs 4 lakh each were handed over to the next of kin of the 16 deceased on Monday after verification of their identity and addresses. “The process of handing over cheques to the relatives of other deceased is underway,” the officer added. Authorities of the affected districts have asked all primary healthcare centres to remain alert till the weather condition improved. In addition, health volunteers have been asked to distribute ORS packets among people in the affected villages on a priority basis, sources in the health department said. Sources said four senior doctors, four assistants and 24 auxiliary midwives (ANMs) have been deployed at the Aurangabad sadar hospital till further orders. Centre's report on Muzaffarpur hospital:.description: The central team sent last week to investigate the death of children from AES in Muzaffarpur has given a damning report regarding the arrangements made for treatment, stating that the paediatric ICU of the Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) did not meet the criteria to qualify as a paediatric intensive care unit (PICU) and that it was only of the level of a high dependency unit. It pointed out that mortality from AES usually ranges from 6-19% in good centres and that mortality was directly proportional to the quality of care the child received at a health facility. In SKMCH, the data shows, mortality rate has been about 25% this year. The central team pointed out that of the 58 children who were admitted to Kejriwal Hospital in Muzaffarpur, there were 7 deaths, or a mortality rate of just 12%. The report listed all the facilities missing in the SKMCH PICU. "Neuroimaging CT Head/MRI facilities should be readily accessible. Presently MRI is not present and CT facility are provided on PPP (public private partnership) mode and patients are not referred for CT scan," stated the report. The report observed that nine ventilators were present but not made operational at SKMCH and no ventilators were present in Kejriwal Hospital. It added that current manpower were "inadequate in quantity and quality" to handle the situation. The team advised better protocol-based management of AES to bring down mortality, improved use of case monitoring sheets and better prioritising of serious and not-so-serious cases to ensure optimal use of resources. It has also recommended constituting a research team from the National Centre for Disease Control, Indian Council for Medical Research, AIIMS Patna, National Institute of Virology, Pune and Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences, Patna to focus research not only on the children who have been admitted with AES but also others within the same geographical area to understand the risks. On the speculation that there may be a link with lychee, the report said that while earlier studies had inferred that this may be connected to the presence of a specific toxin in the fruit, "the work was not sufficient to prove that the toxin is causative for all cases". The multi-specialist team included Dr Arun Singh, national advisor in the health ministry and Dr Ram Singh, an entomologist from National Centre for Disease Control, among others. All departments to have a finance sectio.description: PATNA: All the state government departments would now have a finance section to be headed by an officer of Bihar Finance Service (BFS). Now, the SBI has no role to play in transaction of salaries in the bank account of state government employees. He said salaries in the employees’ bank accounts were being transferred directly from the Reserve Bank of India after introduction of the CFMS. Speaking at the review meeting, the CM stressed the need for better financial management in the state and asked the finance department to be prepared to take additional ‘liabilities’ in the wake of people’s growing aspirations and demands. “Peoples’ income in the state is increasing. Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. 17 more heatwave deaths in Bihar, toll m.description: PATNA: As the intense heatwave continued to take its toll in the state with the body count going up to 78 on Monday, state health minister Mangal Pandey faced a hostile crowd in Aurangabad, which has reported the highest number (33) of deaths so far. Till Sunday, 61 people had died due to heatstroke in the three districts of Aurangabad, Gaya and Nawada in Magadh division. But on Monday, two deaths were reported from Jamui district as well. According to the state disaster management department website, 78 deaths were recorded till 11 am on Monday. Of these, 33 deaths were reported from Aurangabad, 31 from Gaya, 12 from Nawada and two from Jamui districts, respectively. “There have been reports of some more casualties in other districts but details are awaited,” said a disaster management control room official, indicating the casualty figure could be higher. The spate of heat-related deaths in the past two days saw Aurangabad residents raise slogans wave black flags against health minister Pandey when he reached to take stock of the situation with district officials. The minister’s vehicle was held-up and it could proceed only after the intervention of security personnel. The protesters demonstrated against lack of proper infrastructure at the Aurangabad sadar hospital and blamed the large number of deaths on acute shortage of doctors and paramedical staff at the hospital. They were also unhappy at the minister’s delayed arrival to the district headquarters. “There was only one doctor on duty when heatstroke victims started arriving at the hospital for treatment. A huge rush of patients led to chaos at the hospital premises as people frantically searched for doctors. Many of them died due to want of treatment even after reaching the hospital on Saturday evening,” a protestor told the minister. The minister promised to send more doctors and paramedical staff as early as possible. “For the time being, some doctors from Patna have been sent to Aurangabad, who will assist their colleagues attending on the patients affected by sunstroke,” a senior official quoted the minister as saying in Aurangabad. Additional health director (Magadh range) Vijay Kumar said around 150 people had been admitted to various government hospitals under Magadh division, which comprises Aurangabad, Gaya and Nawada districts. Some more patients are undergoing treatment at primary health centres in the region, he added. The state government has already sent out a heatwave alert across the state. A heatwave is declared when temperature remains above 45 degree C for two consecutive days or more. It gets the “severe heat wave” tag when temperature crosses 47 degree C, a disaster management department official said. Health department sources said two teams of doctors have been dispatched from Patna for the worst-hit Aurangabad and Gaya districts. “The health department has issued an advisory asking people to be careful while going out during the day,” sources said. \u2018Hope to nail AES death causes soon.description: NEW DELHI: Litchi toxins, malnutrition, heatwave or poor health infrastructure - what is causing the encephalitis related child deaths in Bihar's Muzaffarpur? Even as the state government blames hypoglycemia as the cause for most deaths, doctors, public health experts and researchers have raised concerns over the government's failure to contain the rapidly rising death toll from the disease. More than 112 children have died due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in the past fortnight and many more are feared infected in Muzaffarpur and the adjoining districts in Bihar. This has also compelled the Union health ministry to send different teams to probe and ascertain the exact cause, strengthen surveillance and measures in the affected districts. Ten paediatricians (including five senior consultants) and five para-medics from RML Hospital, Safdarjung and Lady Hardinge Medical College are part of the five teams set up by health ministry. The teams also include clinical and public health experts from Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), National Institute of Nutrition and UN agencies. "As of now, we do not have much clue about the exact cause of these deaths. However, we are working on several possibilities and are hopeful of zeroing on it in a day or two," a senior official from ICMR told TOI. Experts say there can be a clutch of factors causing AES including viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, chemicals, toxins and non-infectious agents. Though litchis are being seen as a primary cause, researchers say the fruit can only be a contributing factor and not the cause. Instead, prolonged malnourishment, the current heat wave, poor hygiene and lack of awareness about litchi consumption may have led to the significant number of deaths among children, mainly less than five year old. "Litchi cannot be the cause. There is a particular component in the fruit which can contribute to reducing blood sugar level if too many litchis are consumed in an empty stomach," said a public health expert working in Muzaffarpur. Official data suggest the Bihar government has been indifferent towards improving child nutrition and healthcare in this district. In Muzaffarpur, nearly 48% children under the age of 5 are stunted, 17.5% are wasted (too thin for their height), while 42% are underweight--a glaring sign of chronic undernutrition, according to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS)-4. The data also show merely 7.8% children aged 6-23 months receive an adequate diet in Muzaffarpur. While breastfeeding rates are better, the breastfeeding rate in the first hour of birth is poor. Moreover, maternal health indicators are also poor leading to inadequate nutrition for the child despite improving rate of breastfeeding. Every third women (15-49 years) in Muzaffarpur district is malnourished, having body mass index (BMI) below the normal level. Government reports show that 33% women in this age group in Muzaffarpur district are underweight. Experts also pointed at the poor health infrastructure as another major factor leading to deaths. "Delay in care seeking is also a major factor for increasing number of deaths. There is lack of information and awareness. Patients from villages are rushing to town to seek treatment at tertiary care and losing time in the process. If they go to the nearest health centre or clinic, they can get immediate care and the situation can be controlled," another expert with an international health agency said. He added, encephalitis fever usually starts during night and by morning the symptoms are severe, once the fever reaches the brain and damages it, the situation is difficult to tackle even in tertiary care hospitals. So, it is imperative to access care at the earliest. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chandrababu Naidu.description: KURNOOL: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday launched a blistering attack on Andhra Pradesh chief minister and erstwhile ally N Chandrababu Naidu, calling him 'u-turn Babu', whose "intent" was not on state's development. Addressing a well-attended election rally here, he sought to reject Naidu's repeated attacks that his government neglected the state. Andhra Pradesh goes to siumultaneous elections to the 175-member assembly and 25 Lok Sabha seats in the first phase on April 11 with the BJP contesting them alone. Listing various initiatives taken by the NDA government for Andhra Pradesh, Modi said it was during his regime that the Vizag-Chennai industrial corridor was flagged off and approval for the first National Institute of Ocean Technology (NIOT) given. It was also the 'chowkidar' who cleared the first Indian Institute of Packaging (IIP) besides approving the greenfield petrochemical complex for the state, he said. "Five years ago, your one vote made me PM. Your Pradhan sewak worked selflessly day and night for the people of the country. Chowkidar kept the interest of the state in mind," he said. Modi also recalled that the NDA government sanctioned first central university in Anantpur. He accused Naidu, the Telugu Desam Party supremo, of pasting state government 'stickers' on the Central schemes. "For sure, I could have done more work. I just required the cooperation of the state government. I made all efforts from my side, but the person who is running the government (Naidu), his intention is not Andhra Pradesh's development," Modi said. Levelling charges of corruption and dynasty politics against Naidu, he said the election date of April 11 will usher in the "double engine" of the state's growth -- a BJP government both at the Centre and the state. There was debate going on in AP that there were 'schemes for corruption,' ranging from the creation of the new capital Amravati, the Prime Minister charged. "The people of Andhra Pradhesh know whose coffers are being filled.. when this chowkidar sought accounts, u-turn Babu took a u-turn from AP's growth and walked out from NDA," Modi lashed out. Naidu had snapped ties with the NDA in March last year, accusing the Centre of not honouring the "promised" special category status to Andhra Pradesh. Hitting out at the TDP supremo for getting close to the Congress, Modi said Naidu has "found friends who are on bail," apparently referring to Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Sonia Gandhi who are on bail in the National Herald case. Modi, who had in the past hit out at Naidu for alleged family politics, said the election should also see the "son set", and called for a new "sun rise." He deliberately stressed on the "son" part to drive home his point on dynasty politics targeting the AP chief minister and his son and state minister Nara Lokesh. Without elaborating, Modi mocked that Pakistan has now accepted Naidu's "friends" as "hero." Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Bihar: All schools to remain closed till.description: PATNA: The government issued an order on Monday to all district magistrates (DM) and education officers, asking them to shut government and private schools as well as coaching institutes across the state till June 22 due to the prevailing heatwave. Doctors\u2019 strike hits OPD services i.description: PATNA: Most government hospitals wore a deserted look and the OPDs too remained closed as over 12,000 doctors joined the nationwide strike called by the Indian Medical Association across the state on Monday. However, emergency services were exempted from the purview of the strike. The strike was called to protest frequent attacks on doctors across the country. Reena Devi (35), a resident of Kankerbagh in the city, was seething with anger as she had to run from pillar to post for the treatment of her 13-year-old daughter Rita, who was suffering from high fever. The main entrance gate of the Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH), where she was waiting with her daughter, was closed due to the doctors’ strike. “Yahan garibon ka koi sudh lene wala nahi hai (nobody is here to take care of the poor),” a visibly angry Reena said. Like Reena, many from the lower strata of society had to suffer a lot due to the doctors’ agitation in solidarity with their West Bengal counterparts on Monday. One Rohan Kumar (25), who was hit by sunstroke, too had to return from the NMCH due to the agitation. Superintendent of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) Dr Rajiv Ranjan said the emergency wing of the hospital functioned as usual. The scene at Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (AIGMS) was more heart rendering where Janki Devi (35), a resident of Chhapra in Saran district, was wreathing in pain. “I am suffering from arthritis. It’s very painful. I had an appointment with the doctor but he is not present in the hospital. The officials told me that the doctors are on strike and it will continue for a few more days,” she told this newspaper. Similarly, 65-year-old Nand Kishore Mandal, a resident of Madhepura, had to return to his native village as the officials at the premier hospital told him that the functioning had been hampered due to the doctors’ agitation. “Come next time as the doctors are on indefinite strike,” Mandal was told by one of employees of the IGIMS. He too had problem in one of his legs. Dr Anurag Kumar, casualty medical officer at emergency ward of IGIMS said, “We have supported the nationwide strike called by the IMA against frequent attacks on doctors across the country. However, the emergency services were not hampered due to the strike.” Anjit Kumar, a resident of Imamganj in Gaya district, whose cousin was admitted to the IGIMS, corroborated Dr Anurag’s claim. “Emergency services at the hospital were satisfactory. Immediate attention was given to the critical patients,” he said. Around 12,000 doctors joined the strike on the call of the Indian Medical Association across the state on Monday. Patna HC: Paperwork won\u2019t solve enc.description: PATNA: The Patna high court on Tuesday came down heavily on the state government for dealing with the issue of massive encroachments by vendors on several city roads “only on papers” instead of finding a permanent solution. The Patna high court division bench of Chief Justice Amreshwar Pratap Sahi and Justice Anjana Mishra made the verbal remark while hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by Vikash Chandra alias Guddu Baba. The court, while taking strong exception to the issue, suggested the authorities concerned to settle the vendors encroaching upon public roads in front of the residences of ministers so that people could be spared of their sufferings. The petitioner had urged the court to direct the authorities concerned to get rid of roadside encroachments on Ashok Rajpath, Bari Path, Hathua and Lalji markets and the stretch between Pataliputra Colony and Digha road. These encroachments, according to the petitioner, lead to massive traffic snarls in the city. The high court asked the state government to file a counter affidavit by Monday, informing it about the current status of construction of vending zones and settlement of roadside encroachers. The court slammed the government for reappearance of encroachers on roads due to lack of proper vending zones for them. The issue of illegal settlement made below Rajendra Nagar overbridge by the then Patna DM U K Sinha on July 22, 1988, also surfaced during Tuesday’s hearing. The high court had directed the state government to file a reply on the issue on January 15 this year. Patna DM, who filed a counter affidavit on behalf of chief secretary, informed the court that the state government had ordered removal of those living below the bridge at a meeting held recently. Sinha had allowed 214 people to live below the bridge in 1988. The court asked the government to mention in its affidavit the detailed plan regarding eviction of those living below the bridge and their settlement. Additional advocate generals Prabhat Kumar Verma and Prasoon Sinha appeared for the state government and Patna Municipal Corporation, respectively, in the court. Heatwave: Section 144 imposed in Gaya.description: PATNA: The Gaya district administration on Monday issued prohibitory order under Section 144 of CrPC in view of intense heatwave, banning all construction activities, MGNREGA work, public gatherings in open spaces and cultural shows between 11am and 4pm. Acute encephalitis syndrome spreads to n.description: MUZAFFARPUR: The ‘brain fever’ toll in Bihar went up to 114 on Wednesday with seven more deaths even as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases spread to newer areas with reports of children admitted with similar symptoms coming in from Samastipur, Banka and Vaishali districts. Even as more and more cases are being brought in to the Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital in Muzaffarpur, where bulk of the patients are undergoing treatment, the hospital continues to be hampered by lack of proper facilities despite high-profile visits by ministers, including the CM and the Union health minister. TimesViewLittle children dying or suffering permanent brain damage is always a human tragedy, but when official apathy and neglect contirbute to it, that is criminal dereliction of duty. Bihar has seen these deaths happen year after year even if the numbers have in one year gone down and in another shot up. Muzaffarpur has been the epicentre. Given those facts, it is just inexcusable that the government has failed so miserably in ensuring the public health set-up is equipped to cope. Grand schemes count for little if they are of no help to poor families losing their little ones. Of course, tackling this disease needs more than just good PHCs or hospitals. As long as malnutrition is rampant, the problem will remain. To root it out, therefore, adequate nutrition is the first step. But that does not preclude effective medical intervention to ensure that the loss of lives is kept to the minimum if not eliminated altogether.Scarcity of beds and doctors coupled with unhygienic condition prevailed at the hospital even as the Bihar State Health Society issued a list of 15 doctors, technicians and nurses, who have been deputed by the Union health ministry to assist at the hospital in Muzaffarpur. “All 637 beds, including 30 in PICUs, in the hospital are full. We have to put two kids on one bed to accommodate more children,” SKMCH superintendent Sunil Kumar Shahi said. He admitted that there is a shortage of senior resident doctors in every department. “Though there is a shortage, it is inhuman to throw out patients just because we cannot accommodate them. Many of them have come from far-flung villages of north Bihar. Around 40 to 50 new cases of AES … come every day. But our resources are very limited.” To ease the situation, a makeshift paediatrics intensive care unit with 20 new beds and four new ACs were set up on Wednesday amid frequent power cuts. Hospital authorities said 154 children are undergoing treatment for AES at the three PICUs with 10 beds each with fresh cases coming in from neighbouring districts. In Vaishali, civil surgeon I D Ranjan claimed that 15 suspected cases of AES have been reported from Hajipur as well. “Several kids have died in their villages, while others died in the referral hospital before being diagnosed. However, their relatives claimed that they showed similar symptoms of high fever and convulsion among others,” Ranjan told TOI. In Samastipur, at least three of the seven infants with AES symptoms admitted to the Sadar hospital, were referred to SKMCH, one of whom died on the way. However, civil surgeon Siyaram Mishra denied admitting any AES patients at the hospital. Meanwhile, the death of 2-year old child at a village in Katoria block of Banka district due to suspected AES raised alarm in the health department. However, To cope with the situation in Muzaffarpur, DM Alok Ranjan Ghosh has cancelled the leave of all government employees in the district. “The total number of affected and admitted children has gone up to 5,530 since June 1 this year alone. Though, 187 kids have been discharged from the hospital; 101 children are still undergoing treatment at two medical institutions of the district. The conditions of 24 children are critical and have been kept on ventilators,” Ghosh said. “A massive awareness campaign has been started in all blocks with the help of Jiveeka associates and aanganwadi sevikas and sahayeekaa. Executive magistrates have been deployed in every block to monitor the awareness programme apart from keeping a close vigil on the patients, inflicted with AES,” Ghosh added. Bihar encephalitis deaths: Complaint cas.description: PATNA: Social activist Tamanna Hashmi filed a complaint case against Union health minister Dr Harsh Vardhan and state health minister Mangal Pandey in a Muzaffarpur court on Monday, charging them with negligence that led to death of 97 children due to suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in Muzaffarpur and its adjoining districts in the past fortnight. The court of chief judicial magistrate of Muzaffarpur has fixed June 24 as the next date of hearing in the case. The complaint petition said both Dr Harsh Vardhan and Mangal Pandey failed to discharge their duties to contain the disease. Though the two ministers visited Muzaffarpur and took stock of the situation, the death of the children below the age of 10 years continued unabated. The petition alleged that no concrete step was taken by the health department to create awareness and sensitise people in the AES affected areas. The two ministers have been booked under Sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 308 (culpable homicide) and 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) of the IPC. If convicted under Section 504 of IPC, the accused is liable for punishment for two years or fine or both. The accused is liable for punishment for a term of three years after being convicted under Section 308 of IPC and one year under Section 323 of IPC. Most PHCs lack basic infra: Kin of victi.description: MUZAFFARPUR: The acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has proved a nightmare for several villages in Muzaffarpur and its neighbouring districts where people have seen their children dying due to brain fever over the past two decades. Dariapur in Kanti block of Muzaffarpur has dalit and mahadalit population. It has been one of the worst affected villages in the district. The village with a population of hardly 3000 people lacks basic infrastructure even when the government claims all-round development up to hamlets level. Subodh Paswan, whose daughter Nidhi (5) died due to AES earlier this month, blamed lack of medical facilities at local public health centre (PHC). “We took Nidhi to the PHC but they refused to admit her and referred her to SKMCH where she was declared dead. The doctors at SKMCH said her life could have been saved had she been brought a bit earlier,” Paswan said. Sanjay Kumar, another resident of Dariyapur, said the PHC remains open only for three to four days in a month. “Complaints have been lodged with the block officials, but in vain,” he added. Similar was the situation in Damodari, Ramur Sah and other villages from where majority of the AES cases have been reported. Most villagers are either daily wagers or agricultural labourers. Most children seldom go to the nearby Anganwadi centres as they remain open for hardly a couple of days in a month. So, they are deprived of nutritional foods supposed to be distributed through these centres. People have now started preventing their kids from going out in scorching heat, fearing fatal consequences. Even children and parents from urban pockets are apprehensive about the disease. “We are not sure whether this disease will affect our children or not as no urban locality has been hit by AES so far. We are taking precautionary measures and have asked our children not to go out in scorching heat unless necessary,” said Prabhakar Kumar, a resident of Brahmin Toli under the Town police station area of Muzaffarpur. But, in rural areas of the district, every second family is afraid of getting their ward sick and keeps children indoors. “We try our best to not let our wards move out during day time. We are also trying to ensure that our children must not go to the litchi orchards,” said Sakal Paswan of Dariapur Kafen under the Kanti police station area. Also, the tall claims of district health officials of providing manpower and infrastructure to the PHCs and additional PHCs along with referral hospitals of the district seem hollow as majority of the 16 PHCs are reeling from acute shortage of medical experts, nursing staff, apart from beds and other facilities, including medicines. The deadly disease, which was first reported in Bihar at Muzaffarpur in 1994-95, has spread its wings to neighbouring districts of Sitamarhi, Sheohar, East Champaran, West Champaran, Vaishali and Samastipur as well. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome toll climbs.description: MUZAFFARPUR: Fresh deaths due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) have been reported in Bihar's Muzaffarpur district, taking the total number of casualties to 113. The deaths took place at the Shri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH), where 20 fresh cases were brought since Tuesday night. The number of children admitted to the hospital with AES are 372 since June 1, the district administration said. The SKMCH has reported 93 casualties so far and only 118 children have been discharged after treatment. The rest are undergoing treatment or referred to hospitals in the Patna in a critical condition, it said. In the Kejriwal hospital, two fresh cases of the AES were reported since Tuesday night, taking the total number to 146 since June 1. The hospital has so far reported 19 casualties, though none of these took place in the past 24 hours. One death was also reported from the neighbouring East Champaran district on Tuesday. A release by the state health department said 11 medical officers posted in Darbhanga, Supaul and Madhubani had been instructed to leave for Muzaffarpur immediately to help the local health authorities in tackling the outbreak. Three paediatricians posted in other districts have also been pressed into service, while 12 nurses have been directed to report to the the civil surgeon of Muzaffarpur. Anguished by the deaths, a Muzaffarpur resident has filed a petition at a local court against Chief Minister Nitish Kumar, his deputy Sushil Modi, Union health minister Harsh Vardhan, minister of state Ashwini Choubey and state health minister Mangal Pandey. The resident, Mohd Nasim, accused them of negligence, which has resulted in the high number of casualties. The chief judicial magistrate court has posted the matter for hearing next Tuesday. Bihar\u2019s credit-deposit ratio declin.description: PATNA: Bihar’s credit-deposit ratio has declined by 1.29% in financial year 2018-19 compared to 2017-18. It is for the second time in the last 11 years that Bihar has reported decline in its C-D ratio, which indicates how much of the banks’ core funds are being used for lending activities. The state had been reporting constant improvement in its C-D ratio since FY 2008-09, except for FY 2016-17 when it reported decline by 1.05%. As per the credit-deposit data released by different banks at the 68th trimonthly meeting of the State Level Bankers’ Committee (SLBC) held here on Wednesday, Bihar reported 44.09% C-D ratio on March 31 this year, compared to 45.38% in the previous year, resulting in a decline by 1.29%. Different banks in the state distributed Rs1,45,120 crore as loan against the total deposit of Rs3,45,234 crore in FY 2018-19. In the previous years, Rs1,34,997 crore were distributed as loan against the deposit of Rs3,12,829 crore. However, the state reported an increase of Rs10,123 crore in lending in FY 2018-19 compared to 2017-18 when different banks across the state distributed Rs1,34,997 crore as loan. Presiding over the SLBC meeting, deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, who is also the finance minister, expressed concern over decline in the C-D ratio and asked the zonal and regional heads of different commercial, cooperative and private sector banks to take necessary steps to improve it in the current financial year. Modi said two districts — Saran and Bhojpur — reported less than 30% C-D ratio in the last financial year. Saran has reported 29.22% while Bhojpur 29.40%. State’s agriculture minister Prem Kumar, rural development minister Shravan Kumar, industries minister Shyam Rajak, cooperative minister Rana Randhir, development commissioner Subhash Sharma and finance secretary S Siddhartha were present at the meeting, which is usually held after a gap of three months. Being the first SLBC meet of 2019-20, it was scheduled to be addressed by CM Nitish Kumar, but he could not attend it because of his participation in another meeting convened by PM Narendra Modi on the ‘One Nation-One Election’ issue. Later, while briefing media persons, Modi said majority of bank branches in the state were not accepting coins from traders. He said the banks must accept the coins. “I will raise this issue at the state finance ministers’ meet in Delhi on June 21,” SuMo said. He also pointed out that as per the RBI guidelines, loans under the Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme would be provided to only those farmers whose crops are insured under the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana. “But, Bihar government has launched its own scheme, namely Bihar Rajya Fasal Sahayata Yojana, to provide financial assistance to farmers. There should be no compulsion for farmers to join any scheme for availing the loan under the KCC,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Nitish Kumar takes stock as AES kills fo.description: MUZAFFARPUR/PATNA: As ‘brain fever’ killed four more kids pushing the toll to 107 on Tuesday, chief minister Nitish Kumar faced angry protests from the parents and attendants of children undergoing treatment at Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur. Protesters raised slogans such as ‘CM wapis jao’ as Nitish arrived at the hospital to take stock of the situation. He held a review meeting with doctors and health officials and directed senior health department officials to raise the capacity of the hospital to 2,500 beds from the existing 600. He also asked the health officials to double the number of beds in the paediatric ICU of SKMCH. “The capacity must be increased to 1,500 beds in the first phase and later to 2,500 beds. This must be done at priority basis,” Nitish said, adding that the all the renovation work be completed within two years. TOI had highlighted in its reports the lack of beds for the large number of children pouring in with AES symptoms. The health crisis unfolding in Muzaffarpur district and adjoining areas appeared to be worsening by the day as children with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) symptoms are being brought in from Nalanda and East Champaran districts as well. Altogether 43 children from East Champaran are undergoing treatment at SKMCH and Kejriwal Matrisadan in Muzaffarpur. Of the four deaths in the past 24 hours, two are from this district, confirmed Motihari civil surgeon B K Singh, taking the toll from East Champaran to 12. In Nalanda, at least six infants with AES symptoms were admitted to the Biharsharif sadar hospital on Monday and two of them were referred to the Patna Medical College and Hospital late on Monday evening, a hospital official claimed. However, the hospital superintendent denied admitting any AES patients. Despite the protests, the CM and his deputy spoke to parents and attendants of affected children and visited every ward, including four paediatric intensive care units. He spoke to the guardians of all the children undergoing treatment at the PICUs and assured them of assistance from government to save their lives. “They (CM & deputy CM) spoke to the parents and attendants of almost all AES-affected children, but not a single parent complained of any sort of mismanagement or negligence on the part of the doctors at the SKMCH. All parents expressed their satisfaction on the arrangements at the SKMCH,” chief secretary Kumar said. After returning to Patna, the chief secretary, accompanied by principal secretary (health), briefed the media. “CM asked health officials to establish a 100-bed special paediatric intensive care unit (ICU) at the SKMCH in the next one year to deal with the children-related diseases,” the chief secretary said. “The CM asked for more paediatric doctors to be deputed at the SKMCH to assist the existing ones. More doctors from Patna Medical College and Hospital and the Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital are being sent to the SKMCH,” he added. The health secretary said, “At present altogether 31 paediatricians are working at the SKMCH and eight more from other hospitals would be reporting at the SKMCH by Tuesday night.” The chief secretary added that free ambulance service was being provided to AES-affected children and if a parent is forced to hire at his own cost, it would be reimbursed. He also informed that the CM has asked for a dharamshala (rest house) to be built near the SKMCH so that poor parents and attendants visiting the hospital do not face problem of accommodation. “He (CM) collected information about the available human resource at every level apart from infrastructural facilities at the hospital,” said SKMCH superintendent Sunil Kumar Shahi. Uttar Pradesh.description: "You're sitting on my grand mother's grave," Salim Shah told this correspondent. She has been buried, he said, in his living room. A clutch of houses in Chah Pokhar in Achnera block of Agra have turned into graveyards as families are forced to bury their departed in their homes due to lack of a burial ground. As a result, the dead here are a constant part of day-to-day life. TOI found women cooking next to where their children were buried while the elderly rested on cots in a backyard full of graves. In one of the houses, Rinki Begum told TOI that five bodies were buried in her backyard, including that of her 10-month-old son who had died of an untreated fever. Another resident, Guddi, said, "For poor people like us, there is no dignity in death. Due to lack of space in houses, people have to sit and walk over graves. It is so disrespectful." Almost all the houses in the block have graves within the compound Most of the Muslim families here are poor and landless and men scout for work as contract labourers. They said their demand for a graveyard has been ignored for years. The pond in Chah Pokhar village, where a piece of land is allocated for the burial ground on papersThe apathy of the administration can be gauged from the fact that a plot allotted for a graveyard some years ago falls right in the middle of a pond. Repeated complaints have fallen on deaf ears and residents are running out of space. The fresh graves are no more cemented to ensure they occupy less space and stones of different sizes kept over them are the only way to tell them apart. Protests have erupted in the past over the issue. In 2017, after the death of resident Mangal Khan, his family refused to bury his body until land for a graveyard was provided in the village. After assurances by the authorities, they buried Khan near the pond. But the promises came to nothing. Living with the dead: A grave in the backyard"All we are asking for is some land for our ancestors. There is a cremation ground for the Hindus in the periphery of the village, but we are living with our dead," said Munim Khan, a factory worker. Desperate residents even tried reaching out to nearby Sanan village and Achnera town that have burial grounds. But they were not willing to part with precious space. "These two villages have a larger Muslim population than Chah Pokhar. Their burial grounds are filled to capacity," said Nizam Khan, a mechanic. Village pradhan Sundar Kumar said that he had asked officials several times for a burial ground for Muslim families, but no action was taken. Ravi Kumar NG, the district magistrate, said that he was not aware of the issue. "I will send an official team to the village and get details of the burial land required." Heatstroke kills 30 more in Bihar.description: PATNA/NALANDA/NAWADA: The heatwave sweeping Bihar has claimed 30 more lives in the past 24 hours, taking the death toll to 112 on Wednesday. The latest deaths were reported from Aurangabad, Begusarai, Rohtas, Munger and Nawada districts. The toll is likely to increase as unofficial reports of heatstroke deaths are also coming in from Nalanda district. The death count hit the 112 mark, up from 83 on Tuesday, despite western and northern Bihar, including Patna, experiencing a slight fall in temperature due to thunderstorms and light showers. Aurangabad has been the worst-hit with 48 deaths so far, followed by Gaya (35), Nawada (15), four each in Rohtas and Munger, Begusarai (3), Jamui (2) and one death in Nalanda, said Bihar State Disaster Management Authority officials. With temperatures in several districts around 43 degrees Celsius, hospitals are inundated with people suffering from heatstroke. Schools in the state will remain closed until June 23. The number of deaths could rise as a large number of people are undergoing treatment in various hospitals, and some deaths, officials say, are likely to have gone unreported. With the heatwave death toll rising, the district administrations in Gaya, Aurangabad and Nawada have imposed Section 144 CrPc (illegal assembly) to stop people from going out. All labour-intensive work, including construction activities, has been banned between 11am and 4pm. Additional DM of Aurangabad, Sudhir Kumar, confirmed the 48 deaths reported in the district till Wednesday. “We have collected all data from government hospitals and primary health centres. Currently, nine patients suffering from heatstroke are undergoing treatment at the hospitals and PHCs,” Kumar said. The three district administrations, with the help of non-government organisations, have set up water kiosks for residents and anganbadi sevikas are distributing ORS sachets to people. Heatstroke deaths are also steadily rising in neighbouring Nalanda district with doctors claiming 10 deaths in the past four days, including three reported on Wednesday. One of them, a resident of a village under Islampur police station, died on the way to Biharsharif Sadar hospital after being referred by the local PHC, while a 56-year-old man from Amba village under Rahui police station area also died of heatstroke. According to unconfirmed reports, police also recovered the body of an unidentified woman from a field at Kadilpur village under Telhara police station area, who is suspected to have died of heatstroke. Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23.
